I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Strengthening the resilience of flood-prone areas against flooding is an important part of 
the climate change strategy of the Government of India. The National Water Mission of the 
National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC) has identified a need to develop flood 
management strategies for the country and for these to include plans for community-based 
adaption.  The  2012  draft  National  Water  Policy  advocates  structural  and  nonstructural 
measures to avert floods and droughts that include preparedness and coping mechanisms. The 
government is promoting sector reforms at the state level to achieve balanced and integrated 
approaches to flood management. 
 
2.  Flood management is an important facet of climate change adaptation in India because 
rainfall and the risk of extreme rainfall events are expected to increase in large parts of the 
country.  In  September  2011,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  completed  technical 
assistance (TA) that supported the National Water Mission in establishing the requirements for 
effective, coordinated planning processes for climate change adaptation. The TA identified the 
key institutional and reform needs for integrated water resources management. Greater efforts 
are being made globally to achieve a more integrated approach to flood management since 
infrastructure alone cannot deliver the desired results. The steering committee for India’s 12th 
development plan1 has recommended the application of holistic integrated basin development 
and flood management in the country and state governments have emphasized the difficulties 
they face in implementing holistic approaches to flood management.  
 
3.  The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2012–2014 under the 
2012 pipeline.2 In December 2011, the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR) asked ADB to 
support operational research initiatives to help better integrate nonstructural and community-led 
measures into flood planning and management. ADB fact-finding was conducted on 15 February 
and 9 March 2012, to consult the government on the preliminary design of the TA, including 
expected  impact,  outcome  and  outputs;  the  financing  modality;  cost  estimates  and 
implementation schedule and arrangements. 
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
4.  Flooding is a major problem in India, causing significant damage each year. Flood risk 
discourages private investment and contributes to persistent disparities between regions and 
between rural and urban areas. The poor are especially vulnerable, particularly in low-income 
states.3 Low-lying coastal areas are exposed to the combined impacts of the threat of rising sea 
levels and floods. Massive urban spread worsens flooding due to increased runoff produced by 
growing populations and their unplanned expansion into flood plains. Flash floods and flooding 
within  urban  areas  are  a  growing  problem  contributing  to  pollution  and  health  problems, 
especially in urban and periurban areas with poor sanitation. 
 
5.  In 2004, India’s Planning Commission estimated that about 12% of the country’s land 
area, or 45 million hectares were prone to flooding. About 70% of these vulnerable areas, or 32 
million hectares could be provided with reasonable protection, according to the commission. So

far, flood protection and flood management has been provided for about half of this land. 
Climate change is expected to affect agriculture in India through a greater number of extreme 
climate events, including heat waves, droughts, and floods. Unless strong adaptation measures 
are  taken,  many  impact  studies  point  to  severe  reductions  in  crop  yields  in  the  coming 
decades—particularly in South Asia. India’s national and state governments are investing in 
flood management through embankment and reservoir construction, drainage improvements, 
town infrastructure protection, and the raising of villages. Nonstructural efforts have focused on 
flood forecasting, flood warning, and reservoir management. A nationwide flood forecasting and 
warning system has been established by the Central Water Commission. Structural measures 
or engineering interventions are designed to keep floodwaters away from people. Nonstructural 
measures aim to keep people away from floodwaters and help communities adapt to and deal 
with flood threats through prudent land management and disaster preparedness. 
 
6.  As projections of more frequent extreme weather events and thus greater flood risks 
push the expected costs of providing sufficient flood control infrastructure higher, approaches to 
flood management are being reassessed. The engineering-focused approach employed up to 
now in India does not adequately incorporate the benefits and opportunities of integrated flood 
management (IFM). As high-profile disasters such as the failure of the levees around New 
Orleans during Hurricane Katrina in 2005 showed, even communities with engineered protection 
can face significant flooding risks from events such as embankment failure. An integrated 
approach can reduce the human and socioeconomic impacts of floods and incorporate social, 
economic and ecological benefits in the management of flood plains. Examples of nonstructural 
measures that can be mainstreamed to complement structural flood solutions include spatial 
planning, flood plain zoning, provision of relief areas and mechanisms for evacuation; managed 
aquifer recharge in flood zones; wetland management; flood warning, flood insurance, and flood 
compensation schemes and crop planning.  
 
7.  IFM can address flood risks in a holistic way, allowing stakeholders to participate, and 
link  flood  management  with  sustainable  economic  development.  It  provides  flexibility  in 
responding  to  future  flooding  by  using  a  diverse  range  of  instruments  to  manage  flood 
responses. This approach, nonetheless, has made little progress in India despite its successful 
adoption in other parts of the world. More information is needed by planners to demonstrate the 
cost effectiveness and cost-benefit advantages of various integrated interventions. IFM requires 
cooperation and crosscutting institutional mechanisms and planning between the land and water 
sectors and their stakeholders. Nonstructural flood management has been constrained in India 
by institutional and social obstacles to the integration of land management and river basin 
management. This challenge results from the fact that many of the country’s river basin flood 
plains are now densely populated due to unplanned urban sprawl. Other obstacles to the 
adoption of an holistic integrated approach include a lack of (i) well-researched evaluations and 
documented  guidelines  on  the  nonstructural  approaches,  and  (ii)  policy  and  institutional 
mechanisms to facilitate implementation of new integrated ideas and strategies. As a result, 
planners and engineers generally focus on more straightforward engineering solutions alone.  
 
8.  Linkages. A preliminary approach paper for the country’s upcoming 12th five-year plan 
for 2012–2016 called for greater attention to management of water, forests, and land to support 
economic growth. The working group for the plan recommended an integrated basin-wide flood 
management approach, flood forecasting, construction of reservoirs, diversion of flood waters, 
and flood warning systems. ADB’s country partnership strategy for India, 2009–2012 identified a 
need to focus on knowledge solutions, the preparation of operationally relevant knowledge

3 
 
products, exposure to best practices, and promoting learning across sectors and states.4 The 
ADB water operational plan (2011–2020) forecast is more frequent and severe extreme weather 
events in India and states that the effects of such a worsening of weather can be mitigated by 
structural and nonstructural measures such as water governance and flood management.  
 
III.    THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be to increase the protection and resilience of the flood-prone areas in 
India.  The  outcome  will  be  to  improve  knowledge  for  decision  making  and  program 
implementation  of  IFM.  The  TA  will  undertake  operational  research  to  identify  and  test 
integrated flood mitigation and flood plain management strategies appropriate for India. The 
strategies will balance structural and nonstructural measures and provide the mechanisms for 
mainstreaming IFM at different government levels. The TA will help promote change from a 
current narrow, structurally focused flood protection intervention approach in the country and 
support mainstreaming of integrated and holistic management measures. The TA will study one 
focal sub-basin in depth as well as two secondary sub-basins in less detail. The study will 
develop strategies and approaches appropriate for implementation in the focal sub-basin but 
also replicable in other flood-prone sub-basins and states.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented in two phases, starting with phase 1, which will comprise 
scoping  studies.  These  studies  will  involve  (i)  a  review  of  the  lessons  learned  from  the 
integration  of  structural  and  nonstructural  components  of  flood  management  in  India  and 
globally; (ii) identification of the scope and location of the research activities; and (iii) preliminary 
data collection, and support for the phase 2 start-up. Phase 2 will immediately follow from phase 
1 and will comprise operational research to support the mainstreaming of IFM in a way that 
takes into account projected future conditions and climate change uncertainties.  
 
11.  The research will develop proposals for IFM strategies for India. The studies will focus 
on three selected sub-basins, consisting of one focal sub-basin and two secondary sub-basins 
that are highly vulnerable to flooding and encompassing both rural and urban areas. Detailed 
studies will be implemented in the focal basin together with broader, less detailed, parallel 
studies, in the two secondary sub-basins. Through these sub-basin studies it will be possible to 
examine a broad mix of flood and flood management issues. The research will incorporate flood 
risk assessments for key sectors in the selected sub-basins. The research will include a review 
of international experience of IFM. There will be comparison and evaluation of these results with 
lessons learned in the selected sub-basins to ensure that approaches tested in India are based 
on real evidence of effectiveness.  
 
12.  The operational research will (i) be based on international practices in flood mitigation, 
flood risk control, and floodplain management; (ii) explicitly tackle the implications of climate 
change  and  uncertainty;  (iii)  develop  a  balanced  framework  for  a  mix  of  structural  and 
nonstructural flood management measures appropriate to flood situations and community and 
development needs; (iv) incorporate social, economic, and environmental considerations under 
a range of flood scenarios and management options to determine value for money of different

4               
approaches; and (v) develop a participatory and institutional framework to mainstream IFM 
planning consistent with the principles of integrated water resources management and the goals 
of sustainable economic development. The TA will incorporate the following activities:  
 
(i)  It will prepare a detailed review for the focal sub-basin of current approaches to 
flood protection and their effectiveness, including assessments of flood hazards, 
hydrology, and technical measures used for flood protection and management. It 
will draw on experiences globally and in India in the use of existing and emerging 
approaches.  
(ii)  It will assess the impacts of climate change scenarios on flood frequency and 
severity, drawing on linked climate and hydrological models. The risks of error 
propagation from climate and hydrological models will also be evaluated. 
(iii)  It will incorporate social, economic, and environmental considerations under a 
range of flood scenarios and management options to determine value for money 
of  different  approaches.  It  will  assess  constraints  and  difficulties  of 
implementation and prepare a matrix of parameters to support decision making.  
(iv)  It will develop frameworks to assess community vulnerabilities to flooding which 
will  identify  economic  needs  and  opportunities  for  integrated  flood  and  land 
management. Studies will include participatory appraisals to identify the needs 
and  opportunities  for  alternative  approaches  to  flood,  land,  and  watershed 
management. Flood management scenarios will be assessed, disseminated, and 
agreed by stakeholders to support the development of IFM within the selected 
focal sub-basin. Less detailed proposals will be prepared for the two secondary 
sub-basins. 
(v)  The  TA  will  develop  detailed  flood  management  policies  and  frameworks  to 
support  the  mainstreaming  and  effective  implementation  of  the  integrated 
approaches within the focal sub-basin, together with broader recommendations 
for the secondary sub-basins. It will apply the lessons learned to help the national 
and  state  governments  develop  strategies  and  reforms  to  support  the 
implementation of IFM for sub-basins and basins through knowledge sharing and 
training programmes.  
 
13.  Key  research  outputs  will  be  submitted  to  academic  journals  for  peer  review  and 
publication. The topics could include (i) effectiveness of current flood management approaches 
to hydrological changes under climate change, (ii) cost benefits of different approaches to flood 
management,  and  (iii)  strategies  and  reforms  for  mainstreaming  stakeholder-led  initiatives 
toward flood and flood plain management.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1,450,000, of which $1,250,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom and $200,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund5 under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility, both to be administered by ADB. The Government of India will provide office space, 
data, remuneration for research organizations, counterpart staff, and training. 
 
 
                                                      
5   Contributors: the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and Switzerland.

5 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Ministry of Water Resources will be the executing agency. It will appoint a technical 
director at a senior level to oversee TA activities. The study team will work closely with the 
Central  Water  Commission  and  the  state  governments  to  be  selected  for  the  operational 
research studies. The study will build on ongoing research work being undertaken by national 
and international research organizations, including India’s National Institute of Hydrology and 
other  state  water  institutes.  A  project  overview  committee  of  representatives  of  ADB,  the 
Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, and the government will 
monitor TA progress. A project steering panel of specialists and selected stakeholders will 
review and endorse the research outputs. The TA team will liaise closely with the Ministries of 
Environment and Forests and Science and Technology and NAPCC missions. Because the 
government departments and research institutes to be involved in the project lack the necessary 
resources, the TA will require international consultants to achieve the target outputs on time. 
The international expertise will support new methodologies, technologies, and best practices. 
Phase 2 will bring in specialist international expertise of developments in flood management 
around the world. This will enable capacity building in government departments and research 
institutes and the transfer of skills. The TA outputs will be disseminated through awareness 
material, capacity building, training, and workshops. 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented in two phases over 24 months. Phase 1 will be completed 
by month 6. It will require two international consultants for a combined total of 4 person-months 
and four national consultants for a combined total of 12 person-months. Because of the very 
specialized work, the TA will require timely recruitment of highly qualified experts and the 
preparation of high-quality outputs in a short time. For this reason, the consultants for phase 1 
will be recruited individually by ADB in consultation with the government. The recruitment of 
individual consultants will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  Phase 2 will directly follow phase 1 and will include preparation of an IFM plan for one 
focal sub-basin. The plan will consolidate key findings of the studies and present proposals, 
including a well-defined information base to support decision making. A research consortium 
with an internationally recognized portfolio of flood management research will be engaged for 
phase 2. The consortium who will be engaged by ADB will provide five international experts for 
22 person-months and 12 national experts for 84 person-months, who will be engaged using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method at a ratio of 80:20 based on a full technical proposal. 
All equipment for the TA will be processed according to ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as  amended  from  time  to  time).  TA  progress  will  be  monitored  against  the  design  and 
monitoring framework shown in Appendix 1. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.    THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,250,000  to  the 
Government of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom, 
and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to the 
Government of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the 
Water Financing Partnership Facility for Operational Research to Support Mainstreaming of 
Integrated Flood Management under Climate Change, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  India  for  Operational  Research  to  Support 
Mainstreaming of Integrated Flood Management under Climate Change will be implemented 
in two phases. The initial work under phase 1 will be scoping studies to review integrated 
flood management (IFM) practices globally and their application to India and to support 
initiatives to define the scope and location of the research activities. Phase 2 will focus on 
operational  research  and  mainstreaming  of  IFM  under  climate  change.  The  proposed 
consultancy inputs are summarized in tabular form in Supplementary Appendix 1.1  
 
B.  Phase 1: Scoping Studies and Preparation Activities 
 
2.  Strategic planner and team leader (international, 3 person-months). The expert 
should have a master’s degree or equivalent in a water resources management related 
discipline, with more than 20 years of experience in planning and management of water 
resources. Experience should include working as team leader for water resources planning in 
India; and international experience in flood planning and management and climate change 
including experience in technical, social, environmental, and institutional aspects of water 
resources and flood management. The team leader will (i) plan and coordinate phase 1 
activities, (ii) prepare review of international best practices in IFM with other team members 
and assess application and constraints for India; (iii) prepare a matrix and short-list of 
potential study areas for the TA based on flood damage and other information; (iv) undertake 
preliminary assessments and visits to the short-listed locations and present a proposed 
approach for the overall TA, including selection of one focal and two secondary sub-basins; 
(v) support ADB in defining the scope of work and recruitment of the phase 2 operational 
research team; (vi) initiate preliminary studies and activities in the focal sub-basin, including 
hydrometric data compilation, preliminary consultations, and participative appraisals at the 
community  level;  (vii)  establish  initial  databases,  and  (viii)  support  initial  awareness 
initiatives. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of ongoing strategies and initiatives 
for IFM in India and in the focal and secondary sub-basins; (ii) a selection matrix and agreed 
selection of the focal sub-basin and secondary sub-basins; (iii) awareness, training, and 
briefing materials; and (iv) inception and final reports, workshops, training, and raising of 
awareness relating to the scoping studies. 
 
3.  Flood management specialists (international, 1 person-month; national, 4 person-
months). The experts should possess master’s degree or equivalent in water resources-
related disciplines with more than 12 years of experience in water resources programs, 
including experience in hydrology, climate change, and flood planning management. The 
experts will help the team leader define the TA scope and start-up activities. The consultants 
will (i) visit and liaise with the state governments where the focal and secondary sub-basins 
are located to review current approaches and discuss with stakeholders their needs for flood 
management, (ii) compile information and preliminary hydrometric data, a GIS, and other 
databases  for the focal sub-basin, (iii) conduct a review of international best practices in IFM 
and assess the application and constraints for India and the selected focal and secondary 
sub-basins,  and  (iv)  prepare  a  broad  scope  of  work  for  the  TA  and  identify  workable 
mechanisms for upscaling and mainstreaming flood management under climate change 
within the focal and secondary sub-basin states. Specific deliverables will include: (i) a 
review of India flood information and damage data; (ii) a review of ongoing strategies and 
initiatives for IFM in selected sub-basins and in India; (iii) a review of international best 
practices in IFM and assessment of the application and constraints for India and the selected

Appendix 3      11 
 
sub-basins; and (iv) compilation of hydrometric, databases, and GIS spatial data for the focal 
sub-basin. 
 
4.  Institutional specialist (national, 2 person-months). The expert should possess a 
master’s degree or equivalent in social sciences or related subjects with more than 12 years 
of  experience  in  advising  on  institutional  issues  relating  to  water  resources  and  flood 
management. The expert will work with consultants to (i) review the institutional base of flood 
and disaster management; (ii) assess ongoing flood management initiatives with special 
reference to the selected sub-basins; (iii) identify institutional gaps in flood management, 
including a review of the existing role of river basin organizations and the integration of land 
and water resources management; (iv) identify institutional aspects and ongoing programs 
that will support the state and sub-basin selection; (v) support the start-up activities, including 
a program to create awareness of the project; (vi) support the identification of key resource 
persons who may support the study; and (vii) support the establishment of state, central 
government, and stakeholder committees to support project progress and endorse the TA 
outputs. Specific deliverables will include (i) review of current and institutional arrangements 
and development of proposals for the institutional frameworks for IFM for the focal and 
secondary sub-basins, (ii) identification of key resource persons to support the study, and (iii) 
establishment of key stakeholder committees. 
 
5.  Community specialist (national, 3 person-months). The specialist should possess a 
master’s degree or equivalent  in social science or related subjects and have experience in 
conducting social assessments relating to water resources. The expert should have more 
than 12 years of experience in community planning, including experience in the social 
assessment of water resources projects. The expert  will  (i) review ongoing initiatives and 
studies  of  community  participation  and  engagement  in  flood  management  in  India  and 
elsewhere, (ii) identify possible approaches for community participation in flood management 
and in coping with floods in rural and urban areas, (iii) work in the selected focal and 
secondary sub-basins to develop proposals to meet community requirements for sustainable 
flood management, (iv) implement preliminary participatory rural and urban appraisals, and 
(v) prepare recommendations for phase 2 studies relating to community engagement and 
participation in IFM. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of ongoing community 
initiatives and studies relating to flood management, (ii) appraisal of rural flood issues and 
aspirations  in  the  focal  and  secondary  sub-basins,  and  (iii)  recommendations  for  the 
directions of the follow-up research. 
 
6.  Economist (national, 3 person-months). The economist will have a master’s degree 
or equivalent in economics with more than 12 years of experience in economic assessment 
in  the  water  sector.  The  economist  will  (i)  identify  the  preferred  measures  of  cost 
effectiveness and cost-benefit analyses, as applied to flood risk management; (ii) review the 
data available to support value-for-money assessments in states and sub-basins as an input 
into the selection of the focal sub-basin; (iii) bring existing data together for use in value-for-
money assessments; and (iv) prepare an outline approach to primary data collection and 
analytical tools to be used in phase 2. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of cost 
effectiveness and a cost–benefit analysis of different flood management approaches, with 
special reference to the focal and secondary sub-basins; (ii) a review of the economic 
impacts of floods as an input to the sub-basin selection matrix; and (iii) a proposed strategy 
for data collection and analysis to be taken up in phase 2.  
 
C.  Phase 2: Operational Research and Mainstreaming 
7.  Flood  management  specialists:  team  leader  (international,  8  person-months); 
deputy team leader (national, 17 person-months). The experts should possess at least 
master level qualifications or equivalent in water resources related disciplines with more than 
15 years of experience in planning and research of water resources programs, including

12          Appendix 3 
international experience for the team leader. The experience of these specialists should 
encompass hydrology, climate change, and flood planning and management. The experts 
will  be  responsible  for the  overall  planning and quality  assurance  of  the  research  and 
mainstreaming activities, achieving timely delivery of project outputs. The experts will be 
responsible for (i) a detailed performance review of the current flood management strategies 
plans  in  the  selected  focal  and  secondary  sub-basins;  (ii)  preparation  of  a  strategic 
framework for flood mitigation and flood plain management for the focal and secondary sub-
basin, based on fully developed consultative processes; (iii) preparation of an IFM plan, 
including feasibility assessments of sub-projects in the focal sub-basin; (iv) designing the 
mechanisms to mainstream IFM under climate change into planning policy in the selected 
sub-basin states, in other flood-prone states, and by the national government; (v) preparation 
of guidelines for IFM at the sub-basin and basin levels, together with workshops, training, 
and awareness raising; and (vi) identification of key research outputs and coordination of the 
teams research inputs and preparation of research papers for peer review and submission to 
journals.  Specific  deliverables  will  include  (i)  a  performance  review  of  current  flood 
management strategies; (ii) a strategic framework for flood management for the focal sub-
basin, based on consultative processes; (iii) an IFM plan and sub-project feasibility studies; 
(iv) proposals to integrate IFM under climate change into planning policy; (v) guidelines for 
IFM  at  the  sub-basin and  basin  levels;  (vi)  peer-reviewed  research  papers  in selected 
themes  submitted  to  international  journals;  and  (vii)  preparation  of  progress  reports, 
workshops, and awareness programs. 
 
8.   Flood modeller and climate change specialists (international, 6 person-months; 
national,  15  person-months).  The  experts  will  possess  master  level  qualifications  in 
engineering or equivalent and climate change modeling with experience in hydrological and 
numerical modeling. The experts should have 10 years of experience in flood planning and 
modeling, including climate change projections and analysis. The experts will (i) prepare 
climate change projections and run off analysis for the basins relating to the  selected focal 
and secondary sub-basins; (ii) prepare detailed modeling of the different flood scenarios, 
including analyses of different flood management options for the focal sub-basin; and (iii) 
review  ongoing  national  initiatives  for  climate  and  hydrological  information  and  warning 
systems and prepare proposals for strengthening and improving the quality and availability of 
flood warning outputs. Specific deliverables will include (i) climate change projections and 
soil and water assessment tool analyses for the selected pilot basins, (ii) detailed analysis of 
different flood scenarios and management options for the focal and secondary sub-basins, 
(iii) a review of national initiatives for flood warning, and (iv) strategies for mainstreaming 
flood modeling into state and national planning with special reference to the focal and 
secondary sub-basins. 
 
9.  Land use and spatial planners (international, 2 person-months; national, 6 person-
months). The experts will possess master level qualifications in spatial planning relating to 
flood management and have not less than 10 years of experience. The experts will (i) review 
ongoing planning strategies for the flood plain and the associated catchment area, including 
both rural and urban areas; (ii) develop alternative land use management scenarios to help 
support flood mitigation; (iii) work with the socioeconomists to develop workable economic 
models  to  support  integrated  flood  plain  planning  and  zoning;  and  (iv)  support  the 
mainstreaming of land use and spatial planning as an integral part of flood management at 
state and national government levels. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of ongoing 
planning strategies, with special reference to the selected focal and secondary sub-basins; 
(ii) proposals for the selected focal sub-basins for alternative land use management and 
flood zoning strategies to support flood mitigation and economic development;  and (iii) 
proposals  to  mainstream  land  use  and  spatial  planning  as  an  integral  part  of  flood 
management.

Appendix 3      13 
 
10.  Socioeconomists (international, 4 person-months; national, 6 person-months). The 
experts should possess master level qualifications in economics or equivalent with more than 
12  years  of  experience  in  economic  assessments  relating  to  flood  planning  and 
management. The experts will (i) advise on the formulation of basic economic data, covering 
agriculture  and  nonagricultural  production  systems  in  the  focal  sub-basin;  (ii)  review 
socioeconomic trends on the impacts of floods;  (iii) undertake cost effectiveness and cost–
benefit analyses on the different interventions selected for testing; (iv) identify policy and 
economic tools that could be used to support IFM; (v) carry out scenario simulation studies to 
assess potential uptake and economic impacts of alternative flood management strategies; 
(vi) work with the hydrological modeling teams to integrate water and flood management into 
alternative development strategies for the selected sub-basins; (vii)  support the preparation 
of  the  IFM  plan  for  the  focal  sub-basin;  and  (viii)  develop  approaches  to  mainstream 
integrated flood plain management. Specific deliverables will include (i) review of rural and 
economic activities in the selected sub-basins and assessments of the key flood impacts on 
the  rural  and  urban  economies,  (ii)  an  economic  assessment  report  of  the  various 
development and flood management strategies as part of the IFM plan for the focal sub-
basin,  and  (iii)  strategies  and  proposals  to  mainstream  and  integrate  urban  and  rural 
development strategies with flood management and mitigation initiatives for the focal sub-
basin. 
 
11.  Remote sensing GIS specialist (national, 6 person-months). The expert should 
possess  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  remote  sensing  and  GIS,  with  7  years  of 
professional experience in remote sensing analysis. The expert will (i) build up the GIS 
information  to  support  flood  management;  (ii)  compile  all  the  planning  outputs  into  an 
integrated water resources, catchment, and land use information system, and (iii) work with 
the Central Water Commission to review the existing water resources information systems 
used to assess floods; as well as the effective dissemination of flood warning data. Specific 
deliverables will include (i) an integrated land-use and GIS information system for sub-
basins; (ii) a working GIS information system to compile and present user-friendly modeling 
and planning outputs; and (iii)  a proposal for the current water resources and flood warning 
systems in the focal and secondary sub-basins. 
  
12.  Groundwater specialist (national, 2 person-months). The expert should possess a 
master’s degree in engineering or equivalent with not less than 10 years experience in 
groundwater  management.  The  expert  will  (i)  review  current  groundwater  issues  and 
requirements, and (ii) prepare proposals on how flood management could potentially support 
groundwater recharge. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of groundwater issues 
and requirements, and (ii) proposals for flood management to support groundwater recharge. 
 
13.  Agronomist (national, 3 person-months). The expert should possess a master’s 
degree in agriculture or related subjects with 10 years experience in agronomic planning and 
management. The agronomist will (i) review agriculture systems in the focal and secondary 
sub-basins and  include  assessments  of  the  impacts  of  floods;  (ii)  assess  the  potential 
impacts of climate change on agriculture and how changes, including changes to cropping 
calendars, may be made to better meet the needs of flood management; and (iii) prepare 
crop budgets for different cropping scenarios and assess financial impacts of changes to 
cropping to improve flood resilience. Specific deliverables will include (i) detailed agricultural 
systems review for the sub-basins, and (ii) development of strategies for agriculture systems 
to address flood and drought management with special reference to the sub-basins.  
 
14.  Legal institutional specialists (international, 2 person-months; national, 6 person-
months). The experts should possess master level qualifications or equivalent in social 
sciences or a related discipline with more than 12 years professional experience in water 
governance issues. They should possess knowledge of legal frameworks relating to water 
resources. The specialists will (i) review the current institutional and regulatory arrangements

14          Appendix 3 
relating to the water and flood management in the selected sub-basins; (ii) assess the 
necessary institutional requirements for planning and implementing IFM; (iii) identify the 
appropriate institutional arrangements for IFM and control by communities and government 
in  the  selected  focal  and  secondary  sub-basins;  (iv)  develop  appropriate  institutional 
responses to flood warning systems; (v) develop the necessary institutional arrangements to 
support  the  implementation  of  the  IFM  plan,  including  necessary  legal  and  institutional 
reforms for sub-basin and basin management; and (vi) provide legal and institutional inputs 
to the design of the strategy to mainstream integrated flood and flood plain management at 
the state and national government levels. Specific deliverables will include (i) a review of 
current institutional and regulatory arrangements for the focal and secondary sub-basins, (ii) 
proposals  for  appropriate  institutional  strategies  to  meet  needs  of  IFM  and  institutional 
responses to flood warning, (iii) legal and institutional proposals for basin-level IFM and to 
mainstream integrated flood and flood plain management at state and central government 
levels, and (iv) the planning and organization of training sessions and preparation of training 
materials for government staff at different levels and for nongovernment stakeholders.  
 
15.  Social and community specialist (national, 8 person-months). The expert should 
have  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  social  science  with  experience  in  community 
planning and conducting social assessments. The expert should have at least 10 years of 
experience  in  the  social  aspects  of  water  resources  projects.  Specific  deliverables  will 
include (i) a review of community issues and needs in the focal and secondary sub-basins, 
based on extensive consultation and participatory appraisals; (ii) synthesized outputs of the 
community needs to support the preparation of flood management strategies and the IFM 
plan  for  the  focal  sub-basin;  and  (iii)  proposals  to  mainstream  community  needs  and 
initiatives into IFM. 
 
16.  Environmentalist (national, 4 person-months). The expert will possess at least a 
master’s degree or equivalent in environmental science related subjects with 12 or more 
years of experience in environmental planning and assessment, including experience in 
water resources and flood programs. Specific deliverables will include (i) review of the 
environmental impacts of flood management strategies in the focal and secondary sub-
basins and (ii) proposals for integrating environmental conservation with flood and flood zone 
management.  
 
17.  Civil engineer (national, 7 person-months). The expert should possess a master’s 
degree in civil engineering or equivalent with experience in water resources planning and 
management. She or he should have 5 or more years of experience in the planning and 
design of flood protection works, including cost analyses. Specific deliverables will include (i) 
feasibility designs and costings for flood infrastructure requirements to meet different flood 
management options for the focal sub-basin and outline designs for the secondary sub-
basins; (ii) feasibility designs and costings for community flood infrastructure, including flood 
proofing of housing for the focal sub-basin, with outline designs for the secondary sub-
basins; and (iii) development of guidelines for the design of flood infrastructure under climate 
change. 
 
18.  Irrigation and drainage engineer (national, 4 person-months). The expert should 
possess a master’s degree in civil engineering or equivalent with expertise in irrigation and 
drainage planning and management and not less than 7 years of experience in planning and 
design of urban and rural drainage systems. Specific deliverables will include (i) proposals 
and strategies for integrated flood control, drainage, and irrigation in the focal and secondary 
sub-basins; (ii) feasibility designs and costings for urban and rural drainage under various 
flood management scenarios in the focal sub–basin, with outline designs for the secondary 
sub-basins; and (iii) development of guidelines for drainage design, incorporating the outputs 
of the integrated approaches to flood management.
